original_title: Manhattan: South William Street - Broad Street
text:
South William Street, east from (No. 34), but not including Broad, to but not including William Street, showing the New York Cotton Exchange Building (with cone shaped roof-corner) which is situated at the S.E. corner of William and Beaver Streets. Most of these buildings still remain up to the present day (1937) with the exception of Nos. 34 to 28 (three houses in the left foreground) which were replaced by the 35-story International Telephone Building and the 4-story house, seen in the centre background, whose site is now occupied by the 11-story building of the Lehman Bros. banking house. The New York Cotton Exchange Building was also razed and was supplanted by a new 24-story modern skyscraper which is the Exchange's new home.

About 1900.

Brown Brothers.

Pearl Street, at the S. E. corner of Broad Street (right), showing Fraunces Tavern prior to purchase and rehabilitation by the Sons of the Revolution.

Prior to 1905

Gift of Urbrock Collection

Broad Street, north from South William Street. The low buildings on the right were replaced in 1929 by the 35 story International Telephone Building. (No. 67 Broad Street). Shown in the center are tall structures that from left to right.are, the 17 story Johnston Building (subsequently the 48 story Continental Building), the 16 story Mackay (Commercial Cable Co.) Buildings an: the 21 story Broad Exchange Building. The dome seen is atop the Gillenden Building, a structure demolished in 1910 and replaced by the present Bankers Trust Company Building. The 10 story structure at the left is No. 88-64 Broad Street and is at the N.W.corner of Beaver Street. In 1922 this is listed as occupied by the White Oil Company.
April 1906
George L. Balgue

Broad Street, north from South William Street. The low buildings on the right were replaced in 1929 by the 35 story International Telephone Building. (No. 67 Broad Street). Shown in the center are tall structures that from left to right, are, the 17 story Johnston Building (subsequently the 48 story Continental Building), the 16 story Mackay (Commercial Cable Co.) Buildings and the 21 story Broad Exchange Building. The dome seen is atop the Gillenden Building, a structure demolished in 1910 and replaced by the present Bankers Trust Company Building. The 10 story structure at the left is No. 68-64 Broad Street and is at the N.W. corner of Beaver Street. In 1922 this is listed as occupied by the White Oil Company.

April 1906

George L. Balgue

Pearl and Broad Street, corner, showing Fraunces Tavern of Revolutionary fame.
M.B.R.
May 1906.

Pearl Street, at the S. E. corner of Broad Street (right), showing Fraunces Tavern after reconstruction by the Sons of the Revolution in 1905-7. Note the absence of the flag pole on the Pearl Street side over the entrance.

1913

H. N. Tiemann, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection

Pearl Street, at the S. E. corner of Broad Street, showing Fraunces Tavern.. This structure was originally the home-stead of Etienne DeLancey and was erected in 1730. He sold same to Samuel Fraunces in 1762, for a tavern, the "Queen Catherine". The Chamber of Commerce held meetings here. It was Washington's Headquarters and it was from here that he bade farewell to the officers of his Continental Army in 1783. Samuel Fraunces sold it in 1785. The Sons of the Revolution purchased it in 1905 and restored it to the present appearance. Note the tablet on the Broad Street side refering to this act.

About 1915

B. Hellmich, photo
82 W. Broadway, N. Y. C.

Gift of Ubrock Collection

100 Broad Street, west side, at the intersection of Bridge and Broad Streets. Also shown is Bridge Street, north side, west from Broad, to, but not including Whitehall Street. Building shown is occupied by the Bush Terminal Buildings Co.

About 1920.

67-69 Pearl Street, north side Broad Street and coeties Alley, showing P.S. 134.

Board of Education, N.Y.C.
 1920.

Photostat Neg # 395

67 Broad Street, (International Telephone Building) east side, from South William to Beaver Streets, (general view northeastward).

A set of three views along the financial fringe between the East River and Pearl Street ("El" line shown upon same), towards the Brooklyn Bridge.

View No. 1 is towards Wall Street and where appears the Bank of New York, the National City Building, and the Wall and Hanover Building. To the left of these appears the steel framework of the Bank of Manhattan Building. The imposing structure in the center (at Hanover Square) is the N. Y. Cotton Exchange Building.

Views 2 and 3 are similar and show mainly the aforementioned zone. In the third view, the outstanding building is the Seamens Church Institute. Note here the Brooklyn shore in the background.

P. L. Sperr

August 20, 1929
Views: 1-2-3
title: General view - Broad Street - Northwest.

text:
(1) 54-58 Pearl Street, at and adjoining the S.E. corner of Broad Street. Building on the corner (no.54) is Fraunces Tavern.  Also shown on the right, is the east side of Broad Street, to, but not including Water Street.  June 1, 1927. P.L. Sperr.

(2) The same in a westerly direction on Pearl Street across Broad Street and showing also the lower stories of the 16-story N.Y. Telephone Building at the S.W. corner of Pearl and Broad Streets.  This view is towards Whitehall Street and shows at the S.W. corner of same an 8-story structure (white building, right), No. 34-38 Whitehall Street. May 1923. Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

3 c 1930 Nos 8-10 E.L. Armbruster

4 c 1930 Nos 8-11

(1) Pearl Street, east from but not including Broad Street, to and including Coenties Slip. The view shows the Second and Third Ave., Elevated on Pearl Street and turning south on Coenties Slip. (Pearl Street, is arbitrarily set to run north and south when north of Coenties Slip and east and west when south of Coenties Slip).

May 30, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) A more inclusive scene and showing a complete view of Fraunces Tavern, No. 54 Pearl and No. 99 Broad Street, at the S.E. corner of same. This structure was built by Etienne DeLancey in 1719; purchased by Samuel Fraunces in 1762, who ran it as a tavern until his sale of same in 1785. In 1906 the Sons of the Revolution bought same and restored it to its original appearance.

May 1923.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(1) Pearl Street, east from but not including Broad Street, to and including Coenties Slip. The view shows the Second and Third Ave., Elevated on Pearl Street and turning south on Coenties Slip. (Pearl Street, is arbitrarily set to run north and south when north of Coenties Slip and east and west when south of Coenties Slip).

May 30, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) A more inclusive scene and showing a complete view of Fraunces Tavern, No. 54 Pearl and No. 99 Broad Street, at the S.E. corner of same. This structure was built by Etienne DeLancey in 1719; purchased by Samuel Fraunces in 1762, who ran it as a tavern until his sale of same in 1785. In 1906 the Sons of the Revolution bought same and restored it to its original appearance.

May 1923.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

Broad Street, north from Stone Street. In the midground is Beaver Street, with the lower part of the White Building just appearing. Beyond, at Exchange Place, is the Johnston Building. View 2 is slightly later and includes the Blair and the Mackay Buildings above the latter. On the right is the Mills Building. No. 3 is a slightly more inclusive view. Note the pyramidal Bankers Trust Bldg. completed and the final stages of the Equitable Trust Co. Bldg.

Views 1,2: Thomas W. Kennedy, photo
Thru Beecher Ogden
Museum Photographers Assn.

View 3: George L. Balgue, photo

A general view of the easterly side of the downtown Manhattan sector in the Wall Street vicinity, as photographed northeastward from the Produce Exchange Bldg. The East River, the Brooklyn Bridge, and the Brooklyn shore are in the background. Thru the center foreground runs South William Street, traversing the short distance from Broad to William Streets. At that point appears the New York Cotton Exchange Bldg.

February 4, 1927

New York Edison Co.
title: General view - Downtown Manhattan - Wall Street.

text:
100-90 Broad Street, west side, from Pearl to Stone Streets. The small building at the left is the Bush Terminal Building. The block from Bridge to Stone Streets will soon be demolished for the Stone & Webster Building. In the left background is the tower of the Produce Exchange (1885), and the 50 Broadway Building.

April 1, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

Broad Street, west side, north from Pearl (left) to Stone Streets, showing a clearance between the latter point and Bridge Street. South of same is a triangular structure at the apex formed by Pearl and Bridge Streets and which is occupied by the Bush Terminal Co. Note the Produce Exchange in the center of both views being overshadowed by the Standard Oil structure. The photographers vantage point is atop No. 37 Water Street and from which he views north westward over the railed-in roof atop of Fraunces Tavern.

September 20, 1929.
Views 1 and 2.

P.L. Sperr

Broad Street, west side, north from Pearl (left) to Stone Streets, showing a clearance between the latter point and Bridge Street. South of same is a triangular structure at the apex formed by Pearl and Bridge Streets and which is occupied by the Bush Terminal Co. Note the Produce Exchange in the center of both views being overshadowed by the Standard Oil structure. The photographers vantage point is atop No. 37 Water Street and from which he views north westward over the railed-in roof atop of Fraunces Tavern.

September 20, 1929.
Views 1 and 2.

P.L. Sperr

Broad Street (right), north from Stone Street (foreground, street level not seen), as viewed northward from the New York Telephone Building at No. 104. Broad Street. Shown in the background are buildings at Wall Street, consisting of, the Irving Trust (under construction), the Bankers Trust (pyramidal roof), the Equitable, and the Equitable Trust Co. Buildings. To the right foreground is the new 35 storied International Telephone Building, and to the left, the low Produce Exchange.

View No. 2 is the same at an earlier date and photographed in the same direction from atop the roof of the last mentioned feature. To the right in this instance is the 18 story structure (No. 26-28 Beaver Street) shown in the center of the preceding view. Note the absence of the Irving Trust Building and the prominence of the Equitable Trust Co. Broad Street is obscured from view by the buildings on the westerly side of same.

P. L. Sperr.

August 6, 1930.
No. 2 August 28, 1929.

Broad Street (right), north from Stone Street (foreground, street level not seen), as viewed northward from the New York Telephone Building at No. 104. Broad Street. Shown in the background are buildings at Wall Street, consisting of, the Irving Trust (under construction), the Bankers Trust (pyramidal roof), the Equitable, and the Equitable Trust Co. Buildings. To the right foreground is the new 35 storied International Telephone Building, and to the left, the low Produce Exchange.

View No. 2 is the same at an earlier date and photographed in the same direction from atop the roof of the last mentioned feature. To the right in this instance is the 18 story structure (No. 26-28 Beaver Street) shown in the center of the preceding view. Note the absence of the Irving Trust Building and the prominence of the Equitable Trust Co. Broad Street is obscured from view by the buildings on the westerly side of same.

P. L. Sperr.

August 6, 1930.
No. 2 August 28, 1929.

67 Broad Street, east side, from South William to Beaver Streets. This location is that of the 35 storied International Telephone Bldg. which appears in both views with flag atop. To the right in view 2, is the tower atop the Standard Oil Bldg. The photographer is viewing westward along Beaver Street from the 35 stories Wall and Hanover (Brown Bros.) Bldg. Note: in the background beyond Battery Park, the Upper Bay, the Statue of Liberty and the Jersey Shore.

June 26, 1929.
Views 1 and 2

P.L. Sperr

67 Broad Street, east side, from South William to Beaver Streets. This location is that of the 35 storied International Telephone Bldg. which appears in both views with flag atop. To the right in view 2, is the tower atop the Standard Oil Bldg. The photographer is viewing westward along Beaver Street from the 35 stories Wall and Hanover (Brown Bros.) Bldg. Note: in the background beyond Battery Park, the Upper Bay, the Statue of Liberty and the Jersey Shore.

June 26, 1929.
Views 1 and 2

P.L. Sperr

81-71 Broad Street, at, adjoining, and north of the N.E. corner of South William Street. These buildings are being wrecked to give way to the South William Street portion of the International Telephone and Telegraph Building, the first half of which is shown in the background.

May 12, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

84-74 Broad Street, west side, from north of Stone Street to, but not including, Marketfield Street, just south of Beaver Street. The centre building, 80-78 Broad Street, is the Maritime Exchange. This building, and the two adjoining it on the left, will soon give way to the 36-story Maritime Exchange Building.
June 20, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
85-99 Broad Street, east side, from South William to Pearl streets. On the left is the All-American Cables Building; at the extreme right is Fraunces' Tavern.
June 13, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, a year later.
July 8, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
85-99 Broad Street, east side, from South William to Pearl streets. On the left is the All-American Cables Building; at the extreme right is Fraunces' Tavern.

July 8, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

88 to 78 Broad Street (left to right) at, adjoining and
north of the N.W. corner of Stone Street, showing a row of low structures that have been replaced today (1937) by the 36 storied Maritime Exchange Bldg. This organization occupies the 6 story structure (No. 80-78) seen at the right of the view. The 3 story building at the corner will not be included. The photographer owes his vantage point as the Kerr Bldg. and he is viewing south westward across a clearance on the east side of Broad Street and upon which will rise the 35 story International Telephone Bldg. South William Street is in the immediate left foreground and forms one edge of this clearance.
View No. 2 is Westward from the Cotton Exchange Bldg. and the photographer is viewing along South William Street. Note the Produuce Exchange outlined against the Upper Bay with its Statue of
Liberty therein.
P. L. Sperr  August 20, 1929
  View 2: August 28, 1929.

88 to 78 Broad Street (left to right) at, adjoining and
north of the N.W. corner of Stone Street, showing a row of low structures that have been replaced today (1937) by the 36 storied Maritime Exchange Bldg. This organization occupies the 6 story structure (No. 80-78) seen at the right of the view. The 3 story building at the corner will not be included. The photographer owes his vantage point as the Kerr Bldg. and he is viewing south westward across a clearance on the east side of Broad Street and upon which will rise the 35 story International Telephone Bldg. South William Street is in the immediate left foreground and forms one edge of this clearance.
View No. 2 is Westward from the Cotton Exchange Bldg. and the photographer is viewing along South William Street. Note the Produuce Exchange outlined against the Upper Bay with its Statue of
Liberty therein.
P. L. Sperr  August 20, 1929
  View 2: August 28, 1929.

91-97 Broad Street, east side, from Stone to Pearl Streets, inclusive, seen from the Produce Exchange tower. At the right is Fraunces' Tavern.

August 28, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

The same, nearly a year later, seen across the excavation for the Stone & Webster Building.

July 8, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

June 10, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

P. L. Sperr.

An aerial view of 97-105 Broad Street, east side, from Pearl to Water Streets, with the East River and part of the Brooklyn skyline in the background. In the centre is Fraunces' Tavern, a famous eighteenth century inn; it was here that Washington said farewell to the officers of the Continental army, before going into what he expected to be permanent retirement at Mount Vernon.

August 28, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

98-96 Broad Street, west side, from, but not including, Bridge Street, to and including Stone Street. The buildings in the foreground will soon be replaced by the 24-story Stone & Webster Building. No. 88, at the N.W. corner of Stone Street, has just been demolished, and will be replaced by a three-story building.

June 20, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)

98-92 Broad Street, at, adjoining, and north of the N.W. corner of Bridge Street. In the background is the tower of the Produce Exchange.

June 20, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

The same, also showing the Bush Terminal Company at the left. The buildings shown in No. 1 have been demolished and work has begun on the 24-story Stone & Webster Building, which will occupy the block from Bridge to Stone Streets. At the right, the 36-story Maritime Exchange Building is about half finished.

October 3, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)

98-92 Broad Street, at, adjoining, and north of the N.W. corner of Bridge Street. In the background is the tower of the Produce Exchange.

June 20, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

The same, also showing the Bush Terminal Company at the left. The buildings shown in No. 1 have been demolished and work has begun on the 24-story Stone & Webster Building, which will occupy the block from Bridge to Stone Streets. At the right, the 36-story Maritime Exchange Building is about half finished.

October 3, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

98-68 Broad Street, west side, from Bridge to Beaver Streets, inclusive, also showing 11-21 Stone Street, west of, adjoining, and at the N.W. corner of Broad Street. The Stone & Webster Building will rise on the clearing in the foreground. The three-story building on the N.W. corner of Stone Street has replaced a five-story building. The next four buildings, the last of which is the Maritime Exchange, will be demolished for the Maritime Exchange Building.

September 20, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

50 to 36 Pearl Street, south side, west from and including Broad (left), to but not including Moore Streets, showing the 16-story building of the New York Telephone Co. (Nos. 50-42). In the foreground are shown the roof tops of four 4-story units of the Bush Terminal Co., extending, triangularly, westward from Broad Street on Pearl and Bridge Streets. In the background is visible a portion of the East River and the Brooklyn shore.

August 28, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

original_title: Manhattan: South William Street - Broad Street
text:
37-33 and 31-25 South William Street, adjoining and east of the S.E. corner of Broad Street, as seen across clearance at the N.E. corner (site of the present (1937) International Telephone Building).
June 13, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

original_title: Manhattan: South William Street - Broad Street
text:
(1)

43 to 9 South William Street, south side, east from Broad Street, to Mill Lane, showing (foreground) construction work in progress on the 35-story International Telephone Building at the N.E. corner of Broad Street. Contiguous to, and eastward from the construction work, are seen the roof tops of six 4-story houses, Nos. 26 to 14 South William Street. Also shown is a general view eastward of the surrounding area, with the East River and Brooklyn Bridge in the background. This view was taken from the Produce Exchange Building on Broadway, between Stone and Beaver Streets.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

The same, a more limited view. Also shown (centre foreground) is No. 89-85 Broad Street, east side, between Stone (right) and South William Streets. This 8-story building bears also Nos. 25-29 Stone and No. 43-39 South William Streets. On the extreme right are buildings at the S.E. corner of Stone and Broad Streets.

August 28, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

original_title: Manhattan: South William Street - Broad Street

43 to 9 South William Street, south side, east from Broad Street, to Mill Lane, showing (foreground) construction work in progress on the 35-story International Telephone Building at the N.E. corner of Broad Street. August 28, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

24-40 Stone Street, south side, east from, but not including Broad Street, to Coenties Alley. No. 32 (the 3-story house with the gabled roof, in the center of the view), is more than 100 years old, now serving as the home of the American Banker; a bank publication. In 1835, this building had its narrowest escape when the Great Fire of that year, which laid the greater part of that section south of Wall Street in ruins, burned up to the building's side of wall, and went no farther.

August 28, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.
Photostat Neg #A1406

(2)

A view showing prominently the American Banker home at No. 32 Stone Street. To the left is a Manhattan peculiarity, a structure on a 8.10 X 35.6 foot plot, bearing No. 32½.

October 1, 1938

George D. Chinn
Photostat Neg A-1407

text:
Broad Street, west side, north from, but not including, South William Street. In the centre background, the 50-story Irving Trust Company Building is nearing completion.
August 6, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Broad Street, north from, but not including, South William Street. The Beaver Street side of the International Telephone and Telegraph Building has been completed, and work is about to start on the South William Street portion.
August 20, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, but including South William Street, a year later. The second half of the International Telephone and Telegraph Building is now completed. In the background looms the skeleton of the 60 Wall Street tower.
August 6, 1930.

Early New York houses with historical - genealogical notes.
New York: Francis P. Harper, 1900.

Corner of Pearl and Broad Streets. This cannon was captured from a British man of War and Placed in the famous long room of the Frajgncess Tavern, where General Washington took leave of his Offices on December 4th 1783.
